entry.title: Re: DRC eDocument .html file / Tax Payer ID
entry.content:
Hi @chralb 

Thank you for your question. I hope this still helps.

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with DRC for Hungary, the Taxpayer ID used in the XML/HTML structure comes from Supplier Master Data (Business Partner), not from the Company Code settings.

Here is where the Taxpayer ID comes from

  • Supplier Tax Number --> Taxpayer ID is mapped from the Business Partner -->  Identification Numbers section.
  • The field you entered at Company Code level is the VAT Registration Number (Community VAT), which is why it flows into the "communityVatNumber" element instead.
  • For Hungary, the Taxpayer ID is a separate mandatory field and must be maintained correctly in the Supplier Master, which is the Business Partner.

Here is how you can maintain it

  1. Open the Manage Business Partner Master Data app.
  2. Search for the supplier, in this case your Business Partner.
  3. Navigate to Identification --> Tax Numbers.
  4. Maintain the Tax Number Category corresponding to Hungary’s Taxpayer ID.
    • Use the correct country-specific tax type.
  5. Save and re-run the eDocument generation.

Here are some important notes

  • The Hungarian Taxpayer ID must be 11 digits, structured in blocks (e.g. 12345678-1-12).
  • DRC differentiates between Community VAT Number and Local Taxpayer ID. Both can exist in parallel.

See below references for more details:

  • Localization Hungary DRC Withholding Reporting
  • Maintain Business Partner Tax Numbers

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BOP is not working for MTO scenerio
entry.content:
Why BOP is not confirming Sales Orders in MTO (Strategy B6) in your case is because of the following:

1. Strategy Group B6 Behavior
B6 = Make-to-Order with Planning (Planned Order created, linked to sales order). The requirement is sales order-specific, meaning the planned order is tied to the sales order item. ATP logic works manually because it checks the link between the planned order and the sales order directly.

2. BOP “Improve” Strategy
“Improve” tries to reallocate confirmations based on availability and priority (e.g., FIFO). But in MTO, the planned order is not considered general stock—it’s pegged to the sales order. BOP may skip these requirements unless the pegging relationship is properly recognized.

What you can do to fix it are

A. Use Confirmation Strategy “Win” Instead of “Improve”
“Win” forces confirmation of selected requirements if supply exists. “Improve” is more flexible but may not override pegging constraints in MTO. Try switching your BOP variant to use “Win” for MTO segments.

B. Ensure BOP Segment Includes MTO Requirements
In Configure BOP Segment, make sure you include sales orders with strategy B6. You don’t filter out requirements with pegged planned orders. You use characteristics like Requirement Type = KE or Strategy Group = B6.

C. Check Requirement Transfer Settings
Ensure that requirement transfer is active for the sales order item. If requirements aren’t transferred correctly, BOP won’t see them.

D. Schedule BOP Run After Planned Order Firming
Use Schedule BOP Run app to trigger BOP after planned order is firmed. You can automate this via Job Scheduling in SAP S/4HANA Cloud like Job 1: MRP run (firm planned order) and Job 2: BOP run (with “Win” strategy)

Why Manual ATP works but BOP does not is because, manual ATP checks the pegged supply directly and confirms the sales order. BOP, however, uses segments and confirmation strategies that may not recognize pegged supply unless configured properly.

Some of the SAP references are

Confirmation Strategies on BOP by @Andreas_Krause1 

Backorder Processing in Advanced ATP

entry.title: Re: Creating Custom Post-processing of the Output Payment...
entry.content:
Hi @RameshYekambram 

Thank you for your question. I hope this still provides some help.

Here is how this works and why you see the issue:

  1. Why multiple files are generated

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the payment medium workbench generates one output file per payment order.

  • If multiple invoices are bundled into one payment, the system should generate a single file with all items.
  • The behaviour you describe indicates that the file merge happens incrementally and your custom logic is being applied on each iteration instead of once at the end.
  1. Here is why the BAdI is not triggered
  • The BAdI you are using is likely not the correct enhancement spot for post-processing of payment files. In Public Cloud, the relevant enhancement is:
    • BAdI FI_PAYMEDIUM_POSTPROCESS --> Postprocessing of Payment Medium File. This is available in Custom Logic app.
  • If you used a different BAdI for exammple during payment proposal or payment order creation, it will not be triggered at the final output file generation stage.
  1. The correct approach to capture all invoices in one file is to
  • Make use of BAdI FI_PAYMEDIUM_POSTPROCESS. This has been released for S/4HANA Cloud.
  • This BAdI is triggered after the payment file is generated and it receives the entire payment file content. Inside your implementation, you have the possibility to:
    • Access all invoices belonging to the payment.
    • Perform final formatting or concatenation.
    • Ensure that only one file per payment order is produced, with all invoices included.
  1. Here are few checklists you should go through
  • Go to Custom Logic app --> search for enhancement FI_PAYMEDIUM_POSTPROCESS.
  • Implement your logic here and not in earlier BAdIs.
  • Test with a payment run including multiple invoices.
  • Verify that the BAdI executes once per file and contains all items.

The references provide more details:

  • Custom Post-processing of Payment Files
  • BAdI FI_PAYMEDIUM_POSTPROCESS – Business Add-Ins for Payment Medium Workbench

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Expert Advice Needed – Recurring Job Setup in AFC for...
entry.content:
To the question "Can You Schedule a Task to Run Daily Over a Date Range?", the short answer is Not directly as a single recurring task. AFC does not currently support recurrence rules (like “run daily from Day 1 to Day 5”) within a single task definition. Instead, you’ll need to create multiple instances of the same task, each assigned to a specific day.

Recommended approach is to create a Task List Template for your month-end close. Within the template, define five separate tasks for “Automatic Clearing – G/L Open Items” on Day 1, Day 2, ..., Day 5. Assign each task to the appropriate execution date using the Closing Structure Folder or Task List Header Parameters.

To the question How to maintain Dependencies across those days? and how to ensure that “Foreign Currency Valuation” runs after clearing each day, you can use Task Dependencies:

For each day, create a pair of tasks:

  • Task A: “Automatic Clearing – G/L Open Items”
  • Task B: “Foreign Currency Valuation”

In the Manage Closing Task Lists app:

  • Set Task B as a successor to Task A for each day.
  • Use the “Predecessor Task” field to define the dependency.

This ensures that valuation only runs after clearing has successfully completed on that day.

Example Task List Structure

entry.title: Re: Data source extension for outgoing checks
entry.content:
Hi @Melle1028 

Thank you for your question. I hope this still provides some insights.

Yes, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are extensibility options for outgoing checks triggered from the Manage Automatic Payments app and managed in the Manage Outgoing Checks app.

Data Source Extension Availability

  • Extensibility via Custom Fields and Logic App:
    You can extend standard apps such as "Clear Outgoing Payments" which is related to outgoing payments or checks by adding custom fields using the Custom Fields and Logic app. The relevant business context for extensibility is typically the Coding Block (FINS_CODING_BLOCK).
  • Out-of-the-box Reporting or Data Source Extensions:
    While the standard app "Manage Outgoing Checks" allows you to monitor outgoing checks, there is limited direct support for extending its underlying data sources. However, many financial apps allow extensibility through CDS views, OData APIs, or custom analytical queries.
  • App Extensibility Documentation:
    SAP provides documentation on app extensibility, including steps to extend apps via key user tools and business contexts. For specific cases, consult SAP's extensibility guides for Public Cloud and consider if custom CDS or API development is needed for deeper reporting or integration.

If your requirement goes beyond simple field addition, further development with custom APIs or analytical queries may be needed. For direct extensibility in the context of outgoing check management, always check available business contexts and SAP documentation in your system.

Here are some references to guide you.

SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library for "Manage Outgoing Checks"

App Extensibility: Clear Outgoing Payments

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Mapping between Transaction Type and Subitems using GRPL
entry.content:
GRPL doesnt allow for sign based mapping, so you can default 915 to either 921 or 931. After that you can use a sign based Dr Cr reclass rule to assign debit values to 921 and Cr values to 931.
Visual way to see the different mappings between TType and Subitem - There is no mapping as such, transaction types in S/4HANA become Subitems in Group Reporting. Subitems need to be defined as a config item. If you want subitems to be different than the S/4HANA transaction type, then GRPL substitution rules are needed or GRDC mapping. These can only be viewed in the app or the GRDC mapping file.
Ttype to Subitem mapping can be done in GRDC as well and GRDC does support sign based mapping. Impact - additional license cost for GRDC, its not free with Group Reporting, and drill through to accounting documents from Group Reporting will not be possible any more. Plus all the additional set up of import jobs in GRDC.

 

Regards
Vineet

entry.title: Re: Creating Custom Post-processing of the Output Payment...
entry.content:
To the question, why multiple files are being generated, this usually happens when:

  • the output determination logic is triggered per invoice, not per payment.
    the BAdI implementation is scoped to the invoice level, causing it to execute multiple times.
    the system accumulates invoice data across runs, generating separate files with overlapping content.

Here are common causes as to why the BAdI not triggered

1. Wrong BAdI Implementation Point
Ensure you're using the correct BAdI for post-processing:

For payment media output, the relevant BAdIs are typically:

  • FIBL_PAYMEDIUM_X (for classic payment medium programs)
  • BADI_FPAYMEDIUM (for payment medium workbench)
  • BADI_PAYM_OUTPUT (for newer output control framework)

If you're using Output Management (BRF+ based) in S/4HANA Cloud, the BAdI should be BADI_PAYM_OUTPUT_POSTPROCESSING. If this BAdI isn’t triggered, check whether your output type is correctly assigned to the payment method and whether the output determination is set to “Send Immediately.”

2. Output Triggered at Invoice Level
If the output is being triggered per invoice, the BAdI won’t consolidate all invoices into one file. You need to:

  • Ensure the output is triggered at the payment document level (FPAYH), not FPAYHX or FPAYP.
  • Use grouping logic in your BAdI to collect all invoices tied to the payment run.

Follow the below process so that you will get answer to the question "How to ensure a single output file per Payment

A. Group Invoices in BAdI Logic
In your BAdI implementation use the payment run ID or payment document number to group all related invoices. Accumulate invoice data in an internal table. Generate the output file only once per payment document.

B. Use BRF+ Output Control
If you're using SAP S/4HANA Output Management, configure BRF+ rules to trigger output only once per payment document. Avoid multiple output triggers for each invoice.

C. Check Output Parameter Settings
In the Manage Output Parameter Determination app ensure the output type is set to trigger once per payment. Avoid using invoice-specific conditions unless absolutely necessary.

Finally, the link you referred to is part of SAP’s Localization Self-Service Learning Journey, which focuses on customizing output formats. However, it doesn’t cover the execution logic or BAdI behavior in depth. For that, you’ll want to explore:

Payment Medium Workbench 

This page explains:

  • How PMW replaces classic RFFO* programs
  • Configuration steps for payment formats
  • Integration with DME administration
  • Output logs and payment advice generation

Creating Payment Media 

This guide walks through:

  • How to use PMW during payment runs
  • Format-specific mapping and output logic
  • How payment advice notes are generated alongside payment files

entry.title: Re: Cancellation of Depreciation Run
entry.content:
To reverse or cancel a depreciation run in SAP ECC 6.0, especially for Company Code 1000, Fiscal Year 2025, Period 7, you’ll need to follow a structured process. SAP doesn’t offer a direct “cancel” button for depreciation runs, but you can reverse the posted depreciation documents and reprocess them after correcting the asset setup.

Here’s your step-by-step guide:

Step 1: Identify the Depreciation Documents
Use transaction ABGL or AB03 to view the depreciation postings. Alternatively, go to FB03 and filter by:

  • Company Code = 1000
  • Fiscal Year = 2025
  • Period = 7
  • Document Type = AF (Asset Financial)

This helps you confirm which documents were posted during the depreciation run.

Step 2: Reverse the Depreciation Documents
SAP doesn’t allow reversal via AFAB directly. You must reverse the FI documents manually. Use transaction FB08 to reverse each depreciation document:

  • Enter the document number
  • Ensure the reversal date is in the same fiscal year and period (or an open period)
  • Post the reversal

If multiple documents exist, consider using F.80 for mass reversal.

Step 3: Correct the Asset Master Data
Use AS02 to update the asset master record. Fix the incorrect setup (e.g., depreciation key, useful life, cost center, etc.). Save the changes.

Step 4: Recalculate Planned Depreciation
Run AFAR (Recalculate Depreciation) for the corrected asset. This updates the planned depreciation values based on the new setup.

Step 5: Re-run the Depreciation
Use AFAB to re-execute the depreciation run:

  • Company Code: 1000
  • Fiscal Year: 2025
  • Period: 7
  • Ensure “Repeat Run” is selected
  • Run in Test Mode first to validate

Once validated, run in Update Mode to post the corrected depreciation.

Finally and most importantly, Do not use transaction OAGL to reset depreciation in a live system. It’s meant for test environments only. Ensure period 7 is open in OB52 for posting reversals and reprocessing. If fiscal year closing has already been done via AJAB, you’ll need to reopen it using OAAQ before making changes.

entry.title: Re: Change user WO resp not possible batch wise anymore
entry.content:
Some possible workarounds are

1. Mass Change via IW38 or COHV
You can mass update certain fields using transaction IW38 or COHV (Mass Processing). However, “User Responsible” is often excluded from editable fields once the WO is TECO’d. This is by design, as SAP locks certain fields post-TECO to preserve audit integrity.

2. Custom Batch Job Using BAPI
You can use BAPI_ALM_ORDER_MAINTAIN to update WOs programmatically—even for TECO’d orders. This requires a custom report or job, Logic to skip CLOSED WOs, Authorization checks to ensure compliance. This approach has been successfully used by other customers to mass-update fields like cost center, planner group, and user responsible—even post-TECO.

If you need an immediate fix:

  • Ask your technical team to build a Z-report using BAPI_ALM_ORDER_MAINTAIN
  • Filter WOs by status ≠ CLOSED
  • Update “User Responsible” in batch
  • Log changes for audit trail

entry.title: Re: Pack Handling units for multiple Inbound Delivery items
entry.content:
Yes, it’s possible to pack multiple inbound delivery items into multiple handling units (1:1 mapping) using ABAP, but GN_DELIVERY_CREATE has limitations when it comes to complex packing scenarios across multiple items. For more granular control, you’ll want to use function module WS_DELIVERY_UPDATE, which is more flexible and supports packing logic for both inbound and outbound deliveries.

Recommended approach

Use WS_DELIVERY_UPDATE - This FM allows you to assign external HU numbers, Pack multiple delivery items into multiple handling units, Control packing at the item level using table IT_HANDLING_UNITS. Discuss with your ABAP team for key structures to populate.

Some tips are

  • Make sure the delivery items are not already packed or locked.
  • Use VL32N to simulate the packing manually first—this helps validate your logic.
  • If you’re using batch-managed materials, ensure batch data is passed correctly.
  • Refer to SAP Note 581282 for packing via FM/BAPI.

entry.title: Re: EWM, restrict loading with respect to stock type
entry.content:
Some recommended approaches are

1. Use BAdI /SCWM/EX_CORE_LD – Core Loading Check
This BAdI is specifically designed to control loading behavior in EWM. You can implement logic to:

  • Check the stock type of each HU being loaded
  • Check the document type of the outbound delivery
  • Raise an error if the HU stock type ≠ F2 and the document type = sales order. The coding logic should ensure the check is performed at the time of loading, and prevents the HU from being loaded into the TU.

2. Restrict by EWM Document Type
In your BAdI logic, use the document type (e.g., ODSO for outbound sales order) to scope the check. This way, the restriction doesn’t apply to other outbound types like STOs or returns.

To summarize and to implement this

  • Use BAdI /SCWM/EX_CORE_LD to validate HU stock type during loading
  • Scope the logic to apply only for sales order outbound deliveries
  • Optionally restrict manual stock type changes post-picking

This gives you real-time control at the loading point, avoids manual errors, and ensures compliance with your business rules.

entry.title: 🚀 Introducing SCIM API for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2: Seamless User Sync between Source & Target
entry.content:
SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 now supports SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management) APIs, enabling seamless and secure user provisioning from SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) or Customer Identity Directory via SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS).

This integration simplifies identity lifecycle management, ensures compliance, and eliminates manual user creation in the target system (SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2).

To enable in your environment - Request you to create a SAP Support Ticket in Component - CEC-CRM

Its a Feature Flag currently - SCIM API in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is disabled by default.

SSC v2 SCIM API (Official API Documentation - not Released yet)

### Tenant Details but you need to pass the tenant id in the URL
GET {{SSCv2url}}/scim/v2/Users
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}

🚫Important Notes to keep in mind before enabling:

No Manual User Creation Allowed

This ensures that all user data is centrally managed and synchronized, maintaining consistency and reducing the risk of identity mismatches or unauthorized access.

Once SCIM-based provisioning is enabled in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2:

Manual user creation in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is disabled.

When using IPS (SCIM 2.0 based API), only users of type Employee are provisioned. This version introduces an enhanced SCIM API that no longer requires SAP Cloud Integration. It supports patch operations and provisioning of application-specific groups(Business Roles). In addition to pagination using startIndex and count, cursor-based pagination is also supported.

Why SCIM API Matters

SCIM is an open standard designed to automate the exchange of user identity information between identity providers and service providers. With SCIM support in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2, organizations can:

  • Automatically provision and de-provision users
  • Sync user attributes and roles
  • Ensure consistent identity governance
  • Reduce administrative overhead

Benefits of SCIM Integration

  • Automated User Lifecycle Management
  • Improved Security & Compliance
  • Centralized Identity Governance
  • Reduced Manual Effort
  • Scalable for Large Enterprises

Integration Flow:  SAP IAS or Microsoft Active Directory to SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2

Below is the flow diagram illustrating how users are synced from Microsoft Active Directory or/both SAP Identity Authentication IAS to SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 using IAS and IPS:

Flow Breakdown:

  1. Microsoft Active Directory (AD): Acts as the source of truth for user identities.
  2. SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS): Connects to AD via LDAP or Azure AD and serves as the identity provider.
  3. SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS): Pulls user data from IAS and pushes it to SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 using SCIM APIs.
  4. SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2: Receives user data via SCIM and provisions users automatically.

Identity Provisioning (IPS) Documentation - Target System 

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/target-sap-sales-cloud-and-sap-service-cloud 

Final Thoughts

The introduction of SCIM API support in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 marks a significant step toward modern identity management. By leveraging IAS and IPS, organizations can streamline user provisioning, enhance security, and ensure a consistent user experience across systems.

entry.title: Re: Migration Template "Warehouse Stock (new)" - Document...
entry.content:
Hi @talke 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Warehouse Stock (new) migration object is delivered as a standard template via the Migrate Your Data app.

  • The template only provides fields for material, plant, storage location, stock quantity, valuation, etc.
  • Document header text (HeaderText) is not included in the migration object structure.
  • Therefore, it cannot be filled directly via the migration template.

Please note the following standard system behaviour

  • When you migrate stock with the Warehouse Stock (new) object, the system creates an accounting document automatically.
  • However, the header text in MIGO (field BKTXT) is not populated from migration.
  • This is by design becuase migration postings are meant to be technical initial balances.

Here are possible options for you to consider

  1. Standard Limitation
    • You cannot enhance the delivered migration object in Public Cloud to add extra fields
    • Migration templates are SAP-delivered and not extensible.
  2. Alternatively, you can consider following this Workaround
    • If a header text is required for reporting/audit purposes, you could:
      • Post a separate FI journal entry with the desired header text, or
      • Use document number ranges or posting date indicators to differentiate migration postings.
    • For traceability, most customers use the posting date or posting period as migration indicator rather than relying on header text.

Please note that this requirement is not supported in Public Cloud. If it is a must-have, raise a request via SAP Influence Portal or consider a post-migration adjustment posting with the desired text.

For more information, consult the following references:

Migration Object: Warehouse Stock (New)

Data Migration Using Migrate Your Data App

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Skip step in flexible PO workflow
entry.content:
Hi Henrike,

Thanks for the response. Yes, I was looking for the same what you have mentioned.

As already mentioned, BADI SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF allows only one condition ID, so we implemented step-level conditions within the above BADI implementation only as below.

1. Check if the variance is low enough to skip approvals – For auto Approval.

2. Determine the maximum required approval level. Retrieving the current approval level.

3. Identify the latest completed workflow step from table SWWWIHEAD. When each workflow step is completed, we are saving PO number and step level in custom table for later validation usage. 4

. Count how many approvals have been completed and decide if workflow should proceed or not.

This way we could skip the workflow steps when not needed based on the level. However, we felt this is not the best way and not that use-friendly as we must carry out an extra step either deleting PO entries (from custom table ) or refreshing the level to 0 once the process is completed. Above extra step is required for the Restart workflow scenario.

Workflow Features for Purchase Orders | SAP Help Portal – This blog says that we can extend the condition list with additional conditions. However, when I add multiple condition Id’s system will consider only the latest ID at Workflow step level. I cannot see the condition Id at Workflow definition level.

Below are multiple condition ID’s that are added in Implementation through Custom Logic app.

Our expectation is to have separate condition Id’s for Workflow definition and for Workflow step.

Thank you.

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: Re: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Yeah just chime to in, you are free to use whatever, especially for your own build applications, but each SAP cloud is different and uses different things.

  • IAG: P-userid
  • BTP: Whatever you set, often email (with UUID underwater I think)
  • BWZ: Use Global ID (UUID)
  • SAP_BASIS < 753: UserID 12 chars (for which the loginname field is intended)
  • SAP_BASIS > 753: Supports UUID

I assume this will be brought together more down the road. And yes you are pretty free to set whatever in the modular setup, except when you aren't (such as for joule or IAG).

entry.title: Community Feedback List - Disable features for new users
entry.content:
This is how the SAP Community home page looks like today

And it's clear that SAP Community admins are working on that - see Solved: Why Community moderator is not willing to moderate... - SAP Community

@AnnePetteroe wrote:

We were literally just a bit behind because the amount of abuse reports we received! And, we are, of course, in parallell also working on other measurements to prevent spam. More to follow soon.

Those are great news (I personally have reported dozens of times only in the last few months) and I feel the review process is quite fast. Anyway, as it's not clear exactly what the admins are planning, I'd like to give a suggestion that seems to hard - but should fix the spam issue: disabling features for new users. 

Before telling why, let me ask you to please engage in this post in case you agree with the idea so the admins and can know this would be acceptable by the real community users.

Let's see how the profile of such users spamming the community look like. As they will be very likely deleted soon, I am adding images and not links to their profile.

 

We don't need to talk about their content in detail. All those are asking money or talking about money in hindi.

The pattern is clear:

  • New user
  • Short / unreadable name
  • Most likely some weird e-mail address linked with their profile
  • Discoverer
  • Hindi
  • No profile picture
  • Many posts at once
  • Solutions are only for their own posts
  • Usually no blogs - only Q&A content
  • No kudos given/received
  • IP Address?

Inspired by StackOverflow, where you need to engage in order to receive permissions, I suggest that new users should not be able to do much on the community.

For example:

1) New users - read-only access
2) After adding information in your profile (picture, name, link with other social media account (such as Linkedin or Bluesky) then the user should receive some write access
3) Able to ask a single question which are not visible by default and some review will happen so it can be displayed (instead of making it visible and then reviewing after some user report)
4) Not able to ask a second question until the first is marked as solved
5) Not able to accept a solution on your own question
6) Not able to blog until giving X kudos on existing blogs

I hope this change wouldn't be hard to implement - I am not even talking about gamification - it's literally disabling features by default and granting them for real users based on clear criteria

This is way better than asking the community admins to review content.

entry.title: Warnings for exceeding limit on Working Time Accounts
entry.content:
Background

Time valuations generate time valuation results, which provide the basis upon which employees are paid for the time they record. But not all recorded time is paid out immediately. Sometimes the employee works more, sometimes less than the Planned Working Time. For storing this information, a 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐓𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐀𝐜𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭 (WTA) is used. As you can imagine, the WTA moves up and down according to the actual working time. It should be more or less around Zero, but in the reality, it is not.

When the 𝐛𝐚𝐥𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐭𝐨𝐨 𝐡𝐢𝐠𝐡 or low, the Employee, Manager and Time Admin must be aware about it to react. For this purpose, Warning messages or alerts are raised in time sheet.

Challenge/Problem

The 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦 is, that there are 𝐝𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐝𝐬, that must be considered. Most likely, at least for Germany, the Time Sheet is Monthly like the Payroll. There are daily limits that shall not be exceeded (e.g. 10 hours for common employees, 8 hours for underage). There are weekly limits, that shall not be exceeded in the long run (e.g. 48 hours). And the Working Time Account, that is configured Permanent. To bring this different period together, Time Containers are used.

Currently the maximum duration of Period Results is up to 12 Month. A common requirement for companies is that the Working Time Account shall not exceed a threshold (e.g. Standard Weekly Hours of the employee [quite often 40 Hours but depending on the specific employee]) permanently. While the Working Time Account can be configured as Permanent, the Time Container will be reset after 1 year. This leads to the Problem, that Warnings about exceeding thresholds is correct for a maximum of a year, after this they are wrong.

Example:

  • WTA 31.12.25 >>> 30 Hours
  • Time Container 31.12.25 >>> 30 Hours
  • WTA 01.01.26 >>> 30 Hours
  • Time Container 01.01.26 >>> 0 Hours
  • WTA exceeds 40 Hours on 01.02.26 --> Warning should happen
  • Time Container don’t exceed 40 Hours on 01.02.26 since it was reset --> no warning happens

As you can see from the example above, the WTA balance is checked on beginning of every month for Violation or warnings. But since the time container is reset on Jan 1st of every year in this example, the balance calculation can lead to incorrect results in 1st Jan and 1st Feb of 2026. We need to ensure continuation of balance check from previous year 2025 to next year 2026

This situation is described also in the influence request : https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/351707Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

How can we solve this challenge that the balance does not get reset every year and yet we send warning and alerts to employees, managers or admins?

Well, the solution lies in a Custom MDF and Integration centre which can do this job currently of a permanent time container until we build the complete logic in our time valuation engine to cater to this

Solution

We would need to define a custom MDF per user. The custom MDF tracks the balances of WTA every month and checks if the balance is > 40 hours. If yes, it then sends an alert to relevant users like employees , managers etc

Custom MDF structure

Essentially we need three fields

  • The external code is mapped to user
  • cust_AccountDate stores the current date when the balance is checked. For example, the beginning of the month Say Feb 1, 2026. This is useful also for reporting

In case you want to report on this MDF, then it can show the balance as of that date

  • cust_WTABalance stores the actual WTA balance of the employee. The alert is then run against this field by checking the value. If > 40, Alert is sent out for that month to required participants. Else it is ignored completely

 

To handle the alert mechanism, we will have an on Save rule and a Post Save Rule

OnSave Rule

On Post Save Rule (Alert Rule)

In the alert rule, you would also need a workflow config. In the workflow Config, Associate an appropriate workflow step in CC for whom you want to notify e.g.: Employee, manager etc

 

Integration Center:

How is the custom MDF triggered on a monthly basis? The answer is Integration Center. Well without Integration Center, our workarounds would have been lifeless :D.

So thanks a ton to those guys who invented/developed the integration centre 😊

The Integration centre is the final missing piece in the puzzle which runs on a monthly basis (beginning of the month). This then calls the creation/updating of custom MDF.

Once the MDF is saved/updated, the on save rules runs to check the balance of WTA Permanent account and then alert is processed

 

Set up the Integration Center Job for creating the custom MDF object data and triggering its rules
Create a User Scheduled Integration Center Report with below setting

Starting Entity is USER

Target Entity is the custom MDF that you have created

Drag and drop the user ID from the User entity to External Code (User field) of Custom MDF as shown above

Also, ensure that you use operation as Upsert Single/Multiple so that it updates the records of same user the next time

 

Next, its important to set appropriate filters as applicable. For example, if you want to run the Integration Center only for a certain population like German employees,

then add appropriate filers as applicable in filter section

 

Next, Schedule the job to send monthly notifications. Decide this frequency based on your needs.

Note: It is not recommended to schedule the Job daily due to performance impact it can create. Its better to schedule during non-business hours. Also keeping Performance in mind, It is important to select the filters such that you don’t perform the calculation for the whole user group and restrict it only to the required legal entities, Business Units or Departments

You are now done with the setup. Its time to test some scenarios

TESTING

Please note, to test this for different months, I had hardcoded the date for WTA check to 1st Jan 2025 , 1st July 2025, 1st Aug 2025 etc. But in general since IC runs every month, the today() function in the on save rule should pick the correct monthly date. So you don’t have to worry about this

 

Case 1 : Balance >= 40 hours

The employee has a balance of 54 hours as of Jan 1st 2025.

Please note that the balance from previous year i.e Dec 2024 is not reset and it’s a permanent account which is what we want for our scenario

Run the IC for Jan 1st 2025 (simulate) and we see the below

The custom MDF is also updated accordingly and the alert is sent out since the balance as of Jan 1st 2025 is >40

Email/Alert is sent out

Case 2: Balance <40 hours

Lets assume today is Aug 1st 2025, the WTA balance is now 36.5 hours as shown below

Lets run the IC now to see the behaviour

As you can see the custom MDF does not have account date (we would fill it only if >=40). And the balance is updated to 36.5. No Alert is sent in this case

Its flexible. If you want to store account date also for such cases, you could.

In summary, we can track Flex (WTA) account violations every month and the balance is tracked continuously or on a permanent basis without reset issue

Also, you could have this custom MDF embedded in the people profile page . With this the manager can navigate to custom MDF and check the details from profile page of the employee

Hope this helps in your implementation challenges. Do comment on the blog if you like it or have questions

Best Regards

Neelesh

entry.title: Best Practice: Prozessstruktur für Logistik (Leergut-Abwicklung) in Signavio
entry.content:
Hallo Community,

ich arbeite mich gerade in SAP Signavio ein und stehe vor meiner ersten praktischen Modellierungsaufgabe.

Mein Ziel: Ich möchte einen spezifischen Logistik-Prozess modellieren: die Leergut-Abwicklung, bei der auch die Verwaltung der Behälter/Formeinlagen eine zentrale Rolle spielt.

Meine Herausforderung: Um den Prozess sauber abzubilden, möchte ich nicht bei Null anfangen und eine komplette Unternehmens-Prozesslandkarte aufbauen, sondern einen pragmatischen und bewährten Ansatz nutzen.

Meine Fragen an euch aus der Praxis:

  • Gibt es eine etablierte Best-Practice-Struktur für das Abbilden von Logistik-Prozessen in Signavio?

  • Wie organisiert ihr das? Reicht für einen solchen Anwendungsfall eine einfache Ordnerstruktur im Explorer (z.B. Ebene 1: Logistik, Ebene 2: Wareneingang, Lager, Warenausgang)?

  • Kennt jemand eine gute, schlanke Vorlage (Template) für eine Logistik-Prozesslandkarte, die man als Ausgangspunkt verwenden könnte?

Mein Ziel ist es, unnötigen Overhead zu vermeiden und den Prozess so direkt und sauber wie möglich für eine spätere Analyse (z.B. mit Process Intelligence) aufzubauen.

Vielen Dank für eure Tipps und Beispiele aus der Praxis!

entry.title: Does some SAP-provided sample code exist of how to fill the import structure for CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN?
entry.content:
Hi All!

We are currently on a system conversion journey from NW 7.50 to S/4HANA 2023 (see here, here and here for the background). During the custom code conversion we identified several programs which currently rely on maintenance of customer data via batch input or call transaction sessions to XD01, XD02 etc. There are also programs which do the same for vendors via XD01 or some function modules like vender_update.

We are already aware that these programs are basically not "salvagable" but that we need to create new logic utilizing the API class CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN instead. So, over the last couple of days I've searched and found some information on SAP Community (e.g. here or here), SAP Help (high level information) and OSS about how to work with the "unwieldy" import structure CVIS_EI_EXTERN  which goes along with the methods VALIDATE_SINGLE and MAINTAIN of that class. And I'm well aware that "unwieldy" doesn't really do that structure justice as its fully expanded hierarchy view with the many sub-structures and table types comes to about 32,000 lines in a spreadsheet! 

Given the complex inmport structure I'm a bit mystified why SAP on the one hand states that CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN is the way to go in an S/4HANA system for backend customer or vendor maintenance but then doesn't provide some actual sample or demo code which could be used as a starting point to make use of the class.

I'm really thankful for the code examples provided by fellow SAP Community members but am also wondering why we all are basically left to our own devices and have to re-invent the wheel while trying to come to grips with the deeply nested import structure - and without getting cross-eyed and/or confused while doing so!

What I also find somewhat interesting: the class has been around for a few years from what I can tell (there are at least mentions of it in SAP Community going back a few years), but there is no SAP-code at all in our S/4HANA system which actually makes use of it. At a guess, SAP should have code available used to internally test that the class works, before providing it in customer systems. So, I'm wondering if that code - if it does exist - could somehow be made available e.g. in a Github repository?

As you can tell, this perhaps isn't a typical Q&A thread looking simply for an answer to a question, but more the start of an actual discussion thread.

Thanks for reading and I'm looking forward to seeing your replies!

Cheers

Bärbel

entry.title: 🚀☁️ Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud: A Business Transformation Journey
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

📝Introduction

In today’s fast-paced business environment, enterprises are under constant pressure to reduce costs 💰, accelerate innovation 🚀, and stay agile ⚡. Many organizations still run on-premise SAP HANA 🗄️ or ECC systems 🏢, which can limit scalability, slow analytics 📊, and increase IT overhead 🛠️.

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud ☁️ offers a solution: a cloud-native, scalable, and intelligent platform 🤖 that not only modernizes your database but also unlocks new opportunities for business growth 📈, advanced analytics 📊, and AI-driven insights 🤖.

This blog explores the strategic advantages of moving to HANA Cloud, real-world scenarios, migration approaches, and how businesses can leverage this transformation for long-term success 🌟.

1. Why Businesses Should Care About Migration

SAP HANA on-premise has been the backbone of enterprise IT for over a decade. But today, companies face challenges like:

  • 💸Rising infrastructure and data center costs

  • 📉Difficulty scaling for seasonal or global demand

  • ⚡Pressure to innovate with real-time analytics and machine learning

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database upgrade — it is a strategic enabler for business transformation:

  • ☁️Elastic scalability → pay only for what you use

  • 💰Lower TCO → no hardware refresh, no patching overhead

  • 🤖Built-in innovation → multi-model (graph, JSON, geospatial), ML integration, Datasphere

  • 🛡️ Cloud-grade resilience → HA, backups, encryption built in

👉For enterprises planning RISE with SAP, migration is often a key milestone. For GROW with SAP customers, HANA Cloud is already the default foundation.

2. A Real-World Story: Fashion Retailer Migrating During Peak Season

A large fashion retailer running ECC on HANA on-premise faced challenges during peak shopping seasons:

  • 🏬High traffic spikes during Black Friday, festive sales, and seasonal launches

  • 💾Hardware was over-provisioned to handle peak loads but under-utilized the rest of the year

  • 📊Analytics delays slowed decision-making for inventory replenishment, pricing, and promotions

By migrating to SAP HANA Cloud, the retailer was able to:

  • ☁️Scale compute resources elastically during high-demand weeks, then scale down during off-season

  • 📊Integrate sales, inventory, and supply chain data in SAP Datasphere for real-time visibility

  • 💰Reduce infrastructure costs by 25–30% while improving system performance

  • 🛒Optimize promotional planning and inventory allocation by leveraging faster analytics on HANA Cloud

👉Result: Smooth operations during peak shopping periods, lower costs, faster reporting, and improved customer satisfaction — all while creating a foundation for a future move to S/4HANA Cloud.

3.🛠️⚡ Migration Approach: Self-Service Tools for a Smooth Transition

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud can be complex, but SAP provides self-service migration tools to simplify the process, reduce risk, and speed up implementation.

1️⃣Assessment & Planning

  • 🛠️ Review current HANA workloads, database size, and custom code.

  • 📝Decide whether to migrate using sidecar (DB only) or full migration.

  • 🔒Map compliance, security, and network requirements.

  • 📊Identify business processes to migrate first (e.g., analytics sandbox or critical ERP data).

👉Reference: SAP HANA Cloud Migration Guide

2️⃣Execution with SAP Self-Service Migration Tools

SAP HANA Cloud Migration Cockpit / DMO (Database Migration Option):

  • 🛠️ Self-service migration: Provides a guided, wizard-based process for migrating data from on-premise HANA or BTP HANA Service to HANA Cloud.

  • ⚡Supports multiple migration scenarios:

    • ECC on HANA → HANA Cloud (sidecar or full)

    • S/4HANA on-prem → HANA Cloud

    • SAP HANA Service on BTP CF → HANA Cloud

  • 🔄Automated delta replication: Keeps source and target databases in sync until cutover.

  • 🖥️ Validation & monitoring: Allows pre-checks, logs, and real-time monitoring of migration progress.

  • 🔗Seamless integration: Works with SAP tools like SLT/SDI, SUM/DMO, and SAP Cloud Transport.

Key Benefits:

  • Reduces manual steps and risk of errors.

  • Speeds up migration timeline.

  • Provides a self-service experience for IT teams, while still supporting SAP guidance and best practices.

👉Learning resource: SAP Learning Journey – Migrating SAP HANA to HANA Cloud

3️⃣Hands-On Simulation

  • 🖥️ Practice provisioning, configuring, and validating migration steps using SAP’s interactive simulation.

  • 👉Try it here: Enable Now Demo

4. Customer Scenarios: How Migration Helps Different Starting Points

🔹1. Customers on ECC on HANA (on-premise)

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Running legacy ECC (not yet S/4HANA) with an SAP HANA database on-premise

  • 💸Facing high infra + maintenance costs, limited innovation

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️They can move their database layer first (sidecar or full migration) → reduce infra costs immediately

  • 🛠️ This becomes a stepping stone to RISE with SAP (moving ERP to S/4HANA Cloud later is easier if DB is already on HANA Cloud)

  • 📊Can use HANA Cloud for analytics scenarios while still keeping ECC running on-prem

Scenario Architecture:

[💻 Users/Apps]
      |
      v
+-------------------+        Initial Load          +---------------------+
| 🗄️ ECC (ABAP stack)|----------------------------->| ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud   |
+---------^---------+                              +----------^----------+
          |                                                 |
          |   Real-time Delta (SLT/SDI/DP Agent)            |
          +-----------------------------------------------> |
          |                                                 |
+---------+---------+                                       |
| 🗄️ SAP HANA (source)|<----- 🔗 VPN/Private Link/IPSec ---+
+-------------------+

👉Benefit: Lower TCO now, smoother path to S/4HANA in future

🔹2. Customers on S/4HANA On-Premise

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Already on S/4HANA, but hosted in on-premise data center

  • 💸Often invested in large HANA appliances sized for peak loads

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Lift & shift the database layer to HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ⚡Elastic scaling → no more overprovisioning

  • 📊Cloud-native features like multi-model DB and Datasphere integration unlock new business insights

  • 🛡️ Reduces IT overhead (patching, HA setup, backup) — handled by SAP

Scenario Architecture:

                +-------------------+
                | 🗄️ S/4HANA On-Prem |
                +---------^---------+
                          |  🛠️ DMO / Export-Import
                          |  + Optional continuous replication (SLT/SDI)
                          v
                 -------------------------- 🔗 Secure Network -------------------------
                          v
                +---------+---------+       +---------------------+      +-----------+
                | ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud  |<----->| 📊 SAP Datasphere   |<---->| 📊 SAC/BI |
                +---------^---------+       +----------^----------+      +-----^-----+
                          |                           |
                          | 🛠️ Destinations/XSUAA/CAP |
                          +---------------------------+

👉Benefit: Modernized infrastructure, cost savings, easier innovation, and alignment with SAP’s cloud-first roadmap

🔹3. Customers on SAP HANA Service on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry)

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Using managed HANA instances in BTP CF, often for extension apps or analytics

  • ⚠️This service is being phased out in favor of HANA Cloud

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Migration ensures they’re on the strategic, supported database service

  • ⚡Feature parity and beyond (cloud-native scaling, multi-model)

  • 🛠️ Future-proof integration with BTP services like XSUAA, CAP, and Datasphere

Scenario Architecture:

 
+--------------------------------- BTP (CF) ---------------------------------+
|                                                                            |
|  +--------------------+           Data/Schema Move          +------------+ |
|  | 🗄️ HANA Service    |------------------------------------>| ☁️ HANA Cloud |
|  +---------^----------+                                     +-----^------+ |
|            | App Bindings (CAP/UI5/XSA)                      |             |
|            +----------------------------- Rebind/Retarget ---+             |
+----------------------------------------------------------------------------+

“Earlier SAP offered SAP HANA Service on BTP Cloud Foundry, but this has been fully retired and replaced by SAP HANA Cloud. Customers who were using HANA Service have already transitioned or are expected to migrate, since HANA Cloud is the only strategic database service supported by SAP.”

👉Benefit: Mandatory move for long-term support + added innovation opportunities

🔹4. Customers on Non-SAP Databases (Oracle, DB2, SQL Server) with ECC

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Legacy ECC on Oracle/DB2/SQL

  • 💸DB costs + performance issues

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Migrate directly to S/4HANA Cloud on HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ⚡Skip the intermediate step of on-prem HANA investment

  • 📊Immediately benefit from SAP’s innovation roadmap

Scenario Architecture:

[🗄️ Legacy ECC on Non-SAP DB] ---- Extract (ETL/LTMC) ---+
                                                        |
                                                        v
                                             +---------------------+
                                             | ☁️ S/4HANA Cloud    |
                                             +----------^----------+
                                                        |
                                             Standard Content & Mapping
                                                        |
                                                        v
                                             +---------------------+
                                             | ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud    |
                                             +---------------------+

👉Benefit: Leapfrog into cloud ERP without double investment

5. Migration Challenges & How to Overcome Them

While migrating to SAP HANA Cloud brings huge benefits, enterprises may face some challenges. Here’s what to watch for:

  • 🔄Data Volume & Delta Replication

    • Large datasets can slow migration.

    • Mitigation: Use SLT/SDI for incremental replication and pre-validate data mapping.

  • 🔐Security & Compliance

    • Sensitive business data needs encryption in transit and proper role mapping.

    • Mitigation: Configure VPN/Private Link, enforce identity/auth with XSUAA, and follow SAP security guidelines.

  • 🛠️ Custom ABAP Code & Extensions

    • Custom programs may have compatibility issues with HANA Cloud.

    • Mitigation: Test custom code in sandbox or trial HANA Cloud before cutover.

  • ⚡Application & Integration Dependencies

    • Connected apps or BI tools need retargeting.

    • Mitigation: Rebind or redirect connections to HANA Cloud and Datasphere endpoints.

  • ⏱️ Downtime & Cutover Planning

    • Minimizing business disruption is critical.

    • Mitigation: Plan cutover during off-peak periods, validate all delta loads, and communicate with stakeholders.

6. How This Fits with RISE & GROW with SAP

  • 🌟RISE with SAP → Migration is a natural step for existing ERP customers moving to S/4HANA Cloud

  • 🌱GROW with SAP → Net-new cloud ERP customers start directly on HANA Cloud and benefit from innovation immediately

7. Business Outcomes After Migration

  • 💰30–40% lower infrastructure costs

  • ⚡Faster innovation cycles with ML, JSON, graph, and Datasphere integration

  • 🌐Global reach through geo-replication

  • 🛡️ Operational resilience with automated HA and backups

8. Future Roadmap / Innovation After Migration

After migration, enterprises can unlock new business capabilities on HANA Cloud:

  • 🤖Machine Learning & Predictive Analytics

    • Forecast demand, optimize inventory, and personalize offers in retail.

  • 🌐Real-Time Data Integration with Datasphere

    • Connect multiple cloud and on-premise sources for unified analytics.

  • ⚡Cloud-Native Applications

    • Build extensions using SAP CAP, integrate with Fiori/UI5 apps, and leverage BTP services.

  • 🛠️ Automation & RPA

    • Automate repetitive processes and alerts for faster operational response.

  • 🚀Future-Ready ERP

    • Smooth path to S/4HANA Cloud or advanced SAP solutions under RISE with SAP.

Key Takeaways

  • 🚀Migration to SAP HANA Cloud is strategic, not just technical

  • 🛠️ Start with analytics or sandbox workloads first

  • 🖥️ Use SAP guides + Enable Now simulation to de-risk projects

  • 🌟Align migration with your RISE roadmap for long-term gains

entry.title: Re: Error while installing SAP B1 HANA
entry.content:
On the HANA Database Server, go to YaST -> Samba Server -> Select the B1_SHF folder -> Toggle Guest Access to Yes.

Restart the upgrade process from the Windows server.

entry.title: Re: BDCQ - Finance - Needs to be in sync with SAP Best Pr...
entry.content:
Hello @KP_2025 

Thank you for your question. Hope this still provides some support.

you are correct, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the BDCQs sometimes show different descriptions for the same scope item compared to SAP Best Practices scope item documentation.

    • An example is: Scope Item 1QM is officially Advanced Financial Operations in the Best Practices Explorer. In the Finance BDCQ, the same scope item may still appear with the older description (Credit Evaluation and Management).

Here is why the mismatch tends to happen

  • BDCQs are maintained in Central Business Configuration. However, the scope item descriptions in Central Business Configuration may lag behind updates in the Best Practices Explorer.
  • The technical scope item ID (e.g. 1QM) is always the reliable reference, even if the wording differs.

Here is what I recommend

  • Always rely on the scope item ID (e.g. 1QM), not only the text description, when mapping BDCQ to Best Practices.
  • If the mismatch causes confusion whilst carrying out your project work, SAP recommends raising a support incident under component XX-S4C-OPR so that the CBC team can synchronize the descriptions with the latest Best Practice content.

The following references will provide further details:

Central Business Configuration – Business Driven Configuration Questionnaires

SAP Best Practices Explorer – Scope Items

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Down payments for Non-Trade Supplier are not applicab...
entry.content:
Hello @mbanggo 

This behaviour is expected in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public. The Manage Down Payment Request app Only Supports suppliers connected to trade payables' reconciliation accounts.

Non-trade suppliers, such as those linked to other liabilities, are excluded. Consequently, you cannot create down payment requests for them in the standard app.

Possible Workarounds

Manual posting, Use the Post Outgoing Payments (F1612) or Post General Journal Entries (F0718) app to generate the down payment directly and later offset it against the final payment invoice.

Supplier Invoice Request. Alternatively, you can start the payment manually, although this is not a genuine down payment request.

Extension approach: If down payments for Non-Trade suppliers occur frequently, you can consider a custom RAP app or workflow in SAP BTP or In-App Extensibility to replicate the request logic.

Process review. Some customers handle this by reclassifying certain suppliers under trade reconciliation accounts or by using a dummy PO to align with standard functionality.

KBA 3226814 – Restrictions in Manage Down Payment Requests

Down payments through the Manage Down Payment Request app are available only for Trade Suppliers. For Non-Trade Suppliers, you must use manual postings or develop an extension if this is a recurring need.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Number Prefixing
entry.content:
Hello @MikaelaWard 

In the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can differentiate purchase order numbers by assigning distinct number range intervals to various PO document types. This is the standard approach for distinguishing between Stock, Non-Stock, and Service POs.

Configuring instructions

Define Number Ranges for Purchasing Documents

    • Create new number range intervals according to your business needs: 45xxxxxx for Services, 46xxxxxx for Non-Stock

Assign Number Ranges to Document Types

  • Assign each interval to a PO document type. If needed, create custom PO document types for Stock, Non-Stock, Service and link them to their own number ranges.

Notes / Special cases

This approach works for operational purchase orders.F2872 App

Alphabetic number ranges are only relevant for Central Purchase Orders F3292 App(Central Procurement scenario. See KBA 3596398 a for details, though these are not required for standard Pos

You cannot filter number ranges directly by PO created via MRP vs. manually; instead, the differentiation should be based on the PO document type. Assigning unique number ranges to different document types enables you to clearly distinguish between them.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Custom button calling a custom screen
entry.content:
Hello @mollopes 

Yes, it’s possible, but with RAP and OData V4, you won’t create a completely new screen the way we did in old dynpros.

In Fiori Elements, you typically address this in three ways, depending on how different that second screen truly needs to be.

Recommended bound action with parameters for better results.

    • You specify an action in your RAP behaviour by providing input parameters.
    • Fiori Elements makes it really easy by automatically showing a button and a parameter dialogue whenever the user clicks on it.
    • The user fills in additional fields, and you process them in your RAP handler.
    • This provides a pop-up screen without the need to build a new UI.

Navigation to another page or app

  • If you need a separate page, you can use intent-based navigation between two Fiori Elements apps or to a freestyle app.
  • You pass the current entity key as context, so the second app loads the same data plus extra fields.

Custom pop-up through controller extension

    • Add a custom action on the Object Page and open a UI5 dialogue with your own layout.
    • Within that dialogue, you can gather additional input and then manually invoke your RAP action.
    • Useful if you want more control over the UI than the standard action-parameter dialogue.

In the S/4HANA Public Cloud, you can’t create custom database screens or dynpros, so these patterns are the supported approach. For your use case, the same data, plus new fields and process option 1, is the simplest one, with a single button, a single dialogue, and all in line with standards.

Refer to below SAP useful documentation

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

SAP Help –ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

SAP Help – Late Numbering in RAP

SAP Help-ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Issue with BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1 – Reservation Not...
entry.content:
Hello @taher123 

Thank you for the information. Since you are using S/4HANA Public Cloud

MB23 isn’t available on Public Cloud. Use the Fiori apps, such as Manage Material Reservations (F7279), to create or view reservations.

BAPI_RESERVATION_CREATE1 is not a released API in Public Cloud (ABAP Cloud). Even if it returns success, it is not supported, and the document will not appear in the standard Fiori apps.

Alternative supported options.

  1. UI: Create/check reservations in Manage Material Reservations and related display/change apps.
  2. Integration and automation: Utilise the publicly available API for reservations, provided by the SAP API Business Accelerator Hub (A2X OData/REST). Access it through your extension (RAP/BTP Cloud SDK).)
  3. Auth check: Confirm your user has access to the Inventory Management business catalogues that include the reservation apps.

If you share the API you plan to call, I can provide a basic example payload, endpoint, and Cloud SDK snippet along with the exact Fiori app IDs.

With kind regards
Chuma

What’s New in SAP GRC for HANA 2026:

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 builds on the proven foundation of GRC 12 while introducing new enhancements designed for modern enterprises:

Enhanced Integration : Improved connectivity with cloud services, hybrid systems, and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), enabling end-to-end risk visibility and control across environments.

AI-Driven Insights : Initial capabilities in machine learning and automation are being introduced to assist with access pattern analysis, risk identification, and anomaly detection.

Future-Ready Architecture: Built to support S/4HANA 2025 and beyond, with a roadmap aligned to SAP’s long-term strategy, ensuring your GRC investment is secure for the next decade.

Core Modules Supported: SAP GRC for HANA 2026 continues to support the full suite of core GRC modules, now optimized for the new platform:

Access Control – Manage user access, enforce SoD policies, and streamline provisioning with enhanced performance and usability.

Process Control – Automate control testing, monitor compliance in real-time, and gain greater transparency into internal controls.

Risk Management – Identify, assess, and respond to risks across the enterprise with improved analytics and integration.

Deployment and Compatibility- SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is designed to integrate seamlessly into both on-premise and cloud-centric S/4HANA landscapes. Whether you are migrating from GRC 12 or planning a greenfield implementation, the platform supports flexible deployment models to meet your organizational needs.

Key Outliners for the Upgrade Planning:

  • Modern, intuitive UX for business users and compliance teams
  • Faster risk and control analysis with real-time processing
  • Future-proof compliance aligned with SAP’s product roadmap
  • Scalable architecture for complex enterprise environments
  • Enhanced support for hybrid and cloud-first operations

As digital ecosystems grow more complex, organizations need a GRC platform that keeps pace. SAP GRC for HANA 2026 offers a robust, intelligent, and scalable solution for the next generation of compliance and risk management.

entry.title: Re: No pg_hba.conf entry for host in SAP CF PostgreSQL Hy...
entry.content:
hello,
 I also faced the same error in NestJS and TypeORM  with postgres of BTP 
 and this is my solution 

 

@Module({})
export class DatabaseModuleBTP {
  static async forRoot(): Promise<DynamicModule> {
    const creds = JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES || '{}')["postgresql-db"][0].credentials;
    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
    return {
      module: DatabaseModuleBTP,
      imports: [
        TypeOrmModule.forRoot({
          type: 'postgres',
          host: creds.hostname,
          port: Number(creds.port),
          username: creds.username,
          password: creds.password,
          database: creds.dbname,
          ssl: {
            rejectUnauthorized: true,
            ca: creds.sslrootcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
            cert: creds.sslcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
          },

          entities: [__dirname + '/../**/*.entity{.ts,.js}'],
          synchronize: true,
          logging: ['query', 'error', 'log', 'warn', 'info'],
          autoLoadEntities: true,
        }),
      ],
    };
  }
}

entry.title: Re: BTP NodeJS Express API with PostgreSQL Database Conne...
entry.content:
I got the solution of NestJS and TypeORM BTP postgres

import { DynamicModule, Module } from '@nestjs/common';
import { TypeOrmModule } from '@nestjs/typeorm';

@Module({})
export class DatabaseModuleBTP {
  static async forRoot(): Promise<DynamicModule> {
    const creds = JSON.parse(process.env.VCAP_SERVICES || '{}')["postgresql-db"][0].credentials;
    await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
    return {
      module: DatabaseModuleBTP,
      imports: [
        TypeOrmModule.forRoot({
          type: 'postgres',
          host: creds.hostname,
          port: Number(creds.port),
          username: creds.username,
          password: creds.password,
          database: creds.dbname,
          ssl: {
            rejectUnauthorized: true,
            ca: creds.sslrootcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
            cert: creds.sslcert.replace(/\\n/g, '\n'),
          },

          entities: [__dirname + '/../**/*.entity{.ts,.js}'],
          synchronize: true,
          logging: ['query', 'error', 'log', 'warn', 'info'],
          autoLoadEntities: true,
        }),
      ],
    };
  }
}​

Per our understanding of the Standard Commerce Automation scenarios. When we send a PO to SAP Business network from S/4HANA Private Cloud ERP or SAP ECC. So our question is, to send invoices from SAP to SAP Business network, is this the only channel, can we not send the invoices from SAP to Business Network via the MIRO at all? 

Thanks,

entry.title: Re: SAP RAP Events local Consumption
entry.content:
Hello @AshishPandey 

Thanks for the details. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (ABAP environment), RAP business object events, such as R_PurchaseOrderTP → Created, are triggered at commit. If your event binding is set to queued/AT_COMMIT delivery, the handler executes asynchronously after the commit. During debugging, you typically wait at that point, which can make it seem as though the event only functions in debug mode.

Here’s a quick way to check it

Event Binding (ADT)

  • Open the Event Binding of R_PurchaseOrderTP.
  • For testing, set Delivery to IMMEDIATE and activate it. If it fires instantly, the previous behaviour was simply due to async timing.

Binding & Filters

  • Consumer type = Local Handler; Event = Created for R_PurchaseOrderTP.
  • Make sure no filter excludes your test data.

Draft vs. Active save

  • Fiori Purchase Order creation is draft based. The Created event triggers upon activation or final save, like Order, not while still in draft.

Handler class

  • Class is active and ABAP Cloud–compliant.
  • Implements the RAP event handler interface and method signature accurately, for instance:

CLASS zcl_po_evthdlr DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    INTERFACES if_abap_behavior_event_handler.

    METHODS on_created FOR EVENTS created OF r_purchaseordertp

      IMPORTING keys.

ENDCLASS.

If you keep AT_COMMIT

  • Asynchronous delivery uses bgRFC (background Remote Function Call), which is managed in the Public Cloud. Wait a few seconds and check your application logs, such as the BAL application log, to verify it has been executed.

Do you need to run any extra checks on the program?
No. There’s nothing to schedule beyond activating the Event Binding. With IMMEDIATE, the handler runs in the same Logical Unit of Work; with AT_COMMIT, it’s processed automatically.

Develop Event-Based Integration-SAP Help 

ABAP Keyword Doc – METHODS … FOR ENTITY EVENT (handler signature for RAP events) 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Functional area derivation using custom logic in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Functional areas in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are organizational units used for classifying expenses by their nature rather than by operational or geographical divisions. They serve as a key component in cost-of-sales accounting and enable businesses to prepare segmental financial statements for compliance and decision-making purposes. The derivation of functional areas is determined based on the sequence as explained here. In this short blog post, I would like to cover a practical example of how the functional area derivation works using a custom logic substitution rule, which is the last sequence step of the derivation logic. In this demo example, the use case is that the derivation should take place only for the company code 0800, and the default functional area will be substituted by a target functional area which is entered in a custom field of a professional services customer project. The prerequisite is creating and enabling the custom field YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd  in the business context "Work Package".

Step 1:

Create a custom logic implementation for the Extension Point FIN_CODING_BLOCK_SUBSTITUTION

Add the following code: in this example, if the Company Code 0800 is used, the custom logic will substitute the default functional area with the functional area entered by the user into the custom field.

* Note: please always copy the values from input to output first before

* any substitutions, otherwise, the initial values from the output will

* be used for substitutions!!

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING codingblockitem TO codingblockitemout.

 

DATA lv_project_target_fa type STRING.

*Only valid for customer projects, as the custom field is created in this context

IF codingblockitem-companycode = '0800'.

    SELECT YY1_Functional_Area_WP_cpd FROM I_WORKPACKAGE

    INTO @LV_project_target_fa

    WHERE WORKPACKAGE = @codingblockitem-wbselementexternalid.

    ENDSELECT.

    "If the custom field value if empty, no substitution

    If  lv_project_target_fa IS INITIAL.

        EXIT.

    ELSE.

        codingblockitemout-functionalarea = lv_project_target_fa.

        substitutiondone = abap_true.

    ENDIF.

ENDIF.

Next, create the substitution rule for this custom logic to be executed. In the “Manage Substitution/Validation Rules – Journal Entries” app, create a new rule for the business context Coding Block as follows:

 

The precondition determines in which cases the substitution rule will be triggered – in our demo use case, we want the rule to trigger only when the source functional area is equal to 'YB25'. The substitution rule itself simply maps the target field value to the value of the source field functional area (which will be set to a new value during the runtime of the custom logic). So essentially, if the customer project custom field has a target functional area 'YB24' maintained, the default functional area YB25 will be replaced by 'YB24'.

Once this is done, we can conduct a quick test to validate the result. The default functional area determined is YB25, and for our test project XDT0031, the custom field has been maintained with YB24 as the target functional area. After completing a test time booking for the project, the derivation result can be successfully validated in the "Display Line Items in General Ledger" app:

entry.title: FIORI Elements - Button with navigation to DataPage (other Entity)
entry.content:
Hello Everone,

I have following scenario: a instance Action in Entity "A" has declared Entity "B" as Result and should navigate to DataPage of Entity "B". I have implemented this Scenario with OData V2 (it was done with he Manifest.json - the proper Part is assigned) and it works fine.

Now I have to change the V2 Service to V4 and the Navigation don't work. I have tried just to copy the navigation part of  manifest.json but it doesn't seem to be correct (App not started). I have tried to define the self navigation with Routes and Targets (see bottom) but it don't work as well - the navigation is not trigered.

Hier the definition of action

unmanaged implementation in class zcl_bp_i_revision unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for zi_revision
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
{
  action ( features: instance ) NavigateToPlaceInOper result [1] entity zc_in_oper;
}

 The navigation definition in manifest.json for V2 Version (done in BAS, works fine):

entry.title: Re: Link between customer details and material
entry.content:
SELECT
FROM vbak AS sh "Sales Document: Header Data
INNER JOIN vbap AS si "Sales Document: Item Data
ON sh~vbeln = si~vbeln
INNER JOIN mara AS mat "General Material Data
ON si~matnr = mat~matnr
INNER JOIN knvv AS custsalesorg "Customer Master Sales Data
ON sh~vkorg = custsalesorg~vkorg AND
sh~vtweg = custsalesorg~vtweg AND
sh~spart = custsalesorg~spart AND
sh~kunnr = custsalesorg~kunnr
FIELDS    sh~vbeln AS sales_order,
 mat~matnr AS material ,
    custsalesorg~kunnr AS customer,
     custsalesorg~vkorg AS salesorg,
       custsalesorg~vtweg AS distchannel,
         custsalesorg~spart AS division
          INTO TABLE @DATA(l_i_itab)
           UP TO 10 ROWS.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
ENDIF.

 Regards, 
Aniketh B R
